inclusion.criterion: an audiogram performed as standard of care for evaluation and management of chronic tinnitus
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: the UC Davis Otolaryngology clinic and its resource within for this investigation
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: TFI surveys will be provided for the participants
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: 5% lidocaine patches (Endo Pharmaceuticals and Actavis Pharmaceuticals) will be prescribed by a physician in the Department of the Otolaryngology at UC Davis, to be filled at the pharmacy of the participant's choosing
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: the transdermal lidocaine patches will be administered to the participant's torso, either the upper back or chest, at his or her preference
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: patches will be applied first thing in the morning to these areas daily, and kept on for twelve hours
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: the patient will undergo a twelve hour drug recess off of the transdermal lidocaine after patch removal at night
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: all relevant patient information including symptoms checklists, results of TFI, and other important patient care information will be recorded in the UC Davis Electronic Medical Record (EMR) for each encounter under the appropriate encounter subheading
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: the patient data will also be transposed into a REDCap database for patient tracking, evaluation, and analysis
inclusion.label: met

inclusion.criterion: each individual will be asked to complete the tinnitus functional index after the completion of the informed consent
inclusion.label: met

exclusion.criterion: Previous exposure to lidocaine as a treatment for tinnitus
exclusion.label: unknown

exclusion.criterion: Taking medications, herbal remedies and supplements that may interact with lidocaine, including but not limited to antivirals, benzodiazepines, and St. John's Wart
exclusion.label: unknown

notes: The patient is a 14-year-old boy complaining of scoliosis and back pain. He has no other medical condition.
